entry.title: 瞄准苹果无风扇带风扇 MacBook Air
entry.content:

不过，我在微软的演示或该公告的其他报道中没有看到提到的一个警告 - 微软表示这两种设备都有粉丝。苹果仍然在 MacBook Pro 系列中使用风扇，但 MacBook Air 完全没有风扇。在阅读 Microsoft 关于性能的声明时请记住这一点。

  • 戴尔：没有提及。

entry.title: [赞助] WorkOS
微软为 Surface Pro 平板电脑推出全新 Flex 键盘
entry.content:
另来自汤姆·沃伦：

除了新的 Flex 键盘附件外，硬件的基本轮廓没有太大变化。多年来，带有集成支架的平板电脑一直是 Surface 的主要产品，微软仍在继续改进它，而不是试图重新发明它。

我有机会尝试这款新的 Flex 键盘，我很惊讶它比以前的型号稳定得多。当你在桌子上使用它时，没有明显的弹跳，甚至在我的腿上，它比以前的 Surface Pro 键盘感觉更需要学习。

您甚至可以在远离 Surface Pro 的情况下使用此键盘，因为一旦您拔出它，它就会自动切换到蓝牙连接。微软在底座内有一个微型电池，可以在这款 Flex 键盘的触控板上启用此功能以及新的触觉反馈。触觉反馈感觉不像 Surface Laptop Studio 2 那样突出，但这款新键盘的内部仍然很棒。

Flex 键盘的基本理念是，它就像笔记本电脑的底部 - 集成键盘和触控板，还有一个用于容纳随附的 Slim Pen 手写笔的小底座。与 Apple 的 iPad Magic Keyboard 不同，Flex Keyboard 配有电池，并通过蓝牙无线工作。上个月，我在 Federico Viticci 的播客中吐槽了苹果妙控键盘的类似想法。

在我看来，对于平板电脑来说，无线工作的吸引力并不那么大。我不记得曾经希望我的 iPad 妙控键盘通过蓝牙与我的 iPad 保持连接。事实上，当我想通过屏幕键盘单独使用 iPad 时，我发现这很烦人。事实上，妙控键盘只有在 iPad 磁性吸附时才会激活，这一事实有一定的“你知道你会得到什么”的特点。我认为 Flex Keyboard 设计的吸引力在于将其与 Vision Pro 等耳机一起使用。 Vision Pro 对蓝牙键盘和 Apple 的 Magic Trackpad 提供了很好的支持，但是如果您想使用 Vision Pro 来提高工作效率，您需要随身携带两件东西。更好的是带有集成触控板的单个键盘。

微软可以使用这种设计，因为他们一直坚持在 Surface Pro 平板电脑上添加支架。苹果从未发布过带支架的 iPad，而且几乎肯定永远不会。但 iPad 本身没有支架，妙控键盘需要巨大的悬臂式磁性铰链来连接和支撑 iPad，这反过来又使得该设计无法与 Vision 耳机配对。即使新的妙控键盘有电池并支持蓝牙，由于铰链的原因，它也不会成为 Vision Pro 的优雅外设。

因此，微软有一个集成的键盘/触控板外设，看起来非常适合与耳机一起使用，但他们只生产似乎没有人关心的耳机。苹果有一款带有集成键盘/触控板的耳机，但他们的集成键盘/触控板是专为新款 iPad Pro 设计的。

带超薄笔的 Flex 键盘也不便宜：450 美元。 13 英寸 iPad Magic Keyboard 售价 330 美元，Pencil Pro 售价 130 美元。

★

entry.title: 《微软击败 MacBook Air 的使命》
entry.content:
汤姆·沃伦（Tom Warren）为 The Verge 撰文：

最近的一个早上，微软代表在华盛顿州雷德蒙德总部展示了配备高通 Snapdragon X Elite 芯片的 新款 Surface 设备，并将其与苹果领先的笔记本电脑进行了直接比较。我目睹了一个小时的演示和基准测试，从 Geekbench 和 Cinebench 比较开始，然后转向应用程序和兼容性。

基准测试通常看起来并不那么令人兴奋。但这里存在很多风险：多年来，MacBook Air 一直能够使用基于 Arm 的 PC 芯片——以及基于英特尔的芯片。只不过，这一次，Surface 在第一次测试中取得了领先。然后它又赢得了一次又一次的测试。这些测试的结果是微软相信它现在有能力征服笔记本电脑市场的原因。

微软的比较全部针对 M3 MacBook Air 型号。公平地说，MacBook Air 是迄今为止苹果最畅销的笔记本电脑系列，而 M3 型号才两个月前发货。但 MacBook Air 没有风扇。很多——大多数？全部？我不确定微软今天展示的新型“Copilot+ PC”是否有粉丝。 （或者，如果您更喜欢，“主动冷却系统”。）微软自己的新款 Surface 笔记本电脑的定价与 MacBook-Air 类似（13 英寸起价为 1000 美元；15 英寸起价为 1300 美元），但它们比同类产品重约 0.3 磅尺寸的 MacBook Air。这些重量使其更接近 M2 13 英寸 MacBook Pro 的级别。

不过，如果没有电池寿命，所有这些应用程序的兼容性和性能都将毫无意义。微软使用脚本来模拟网页浏览。在 2022 年基于英特尔的 Surface Laptop 5 上，电池完全耗尽需要 8 小时 38 分钟；新款 Surface Copilot Plus PC 的续航时间是这个数字的三倍，达到 16 小时 56 分钟。这是令人难以置信的效率飞跃，甚至超过了在 15 英寸 MacBook Air M3 上进行的相同测试，该测试持续了 15 小时 25 分钟。那又是整整一个半小时了。

微软对视频播放进行了类似的测试，Surface Copilot Plus PC 在测试中达到了 20 多个小时，MacBook Air M3 达到了 17 小时 45 分钟。这也比 Surface Laptop 5 多了近 8 个小时，后者持续了 12 小时 30 分钟。如果这些电池增益超出了基本的网页浏览和视频播放的范围，这对于 Windows 笔记本电脑来说将是一个重大改进。

我猜 Warren 的意思是，新款 Surface 笔记本电脑的使用寿命是基于英特尔的旧型号的两倍，而不是三倍。但这凸显了我从今天的活动中得到的主要硬件收获：M3 MacBook Air 充当了所有这些比较（性能、电池、价格）的良好陪衬/基准，但真正的比较是高通的 Snapdragon X Elite 与英特尔和 AMD 的 x86 产品。

我敢说今天标志着 x86 终结的开始。要么x86架构已经达到了不可避免的终点，要么Intel和AMD无法在人才方面进行竞争。 （或者两者兼而有之。）但时至今日，ARM 和 Intel/x86 之间的每瓦性能差距不再只是 Apple 芯片的问题，现在也成为 PC 的问题。如果英特尔或 AMD 有机会迎头赶上，那一定是在 2020 年 M1 突破性推出至今之间。但他们做不到。

此次活动中最令人悲伤的部分是英特尔首席执行官帕特·基辛格(Pat Gelsinger)和AMD首席执行官苏姿丰(Lisa Su)的匆匆露面——尽管这是在雷德蒙德举行的现场活动，但都是通过预先录制的视频出现的。他们象征性的出现感觉就像微软在一次活动中假装他们没有从 x86 继续前进，而整个活动的主题实际上是“从 x86 继续前进”。高通的 Snapdragon X Elite 仅与苹果的基础 M3 进行比较，因此英特尔和 AMD 仍需提供性能与 M3 Pro 和 Max 水平相当的芯片，但这是不祥之兆。未来属于ARM系统架构。

★
;

entry.title: 微软推出“Copilot+ PC”
entry.content:
微软今天在 Build 开发者大会前夕举办了一场活动，介绍其全新的“AI 优先”级 PC，他们将其称为 Copilot+ PC。该活动视频不在 YouTube 上（还没有？），并且 URL ( https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/event ) 不是永久链接。

最值得注意的 Windows 新功能是 Recall（它在概念上看起来很像Rewind ，它已经作为 MacOS 的第三方应用程序提供了一段时间）：

我们着手解决我们每天遇到的最令人沮丧的问题之一——找到我们以前在电脑上见过的东西。今天，我们必须记住它存储在哪个文件夹中，它位于哪个网站上，或者滚动浏览数百封电子邮件试图找到它。

现在，借助 Recall，您可以虚拟地访问您在 PC 上看到或做过的事情，就像拥有过目不忘的记忆一样。 Copilot+ PC 像我们一样根据我们每个人的经历所特有的关系和关联来组织信息。这可以帮助您记住可能忘记的事情，这样您只需使用您记住的提示即可快速直观地找到您要查找的内容。 [...]

Recall 利用您的个人语义索引，该索引完全构建并存储在您的设备上。你的快照是你的；它们保留在您的本地电脑上。您可以删除单个快照，在“设置”中调整和删除时间范围，或者直接通过任务栏上系统托盘中的图标随时暂停。您还可以过滤不保存的应用程序和网站。您始终掌控着值得信赖的隐私。

Recall 可以“查看”并记住屏幕上出现的所有内容，因为它与 Windows 11 图形系统集成。这是一种真正受益于第一方解决方案的“人工智能功能”，它可以在比第三方应用程序更低的操作系统级别进行集成。

他们展示的最令人印象深刻的演示之一是使用 Copilot 作为语音驱动助手，帮助您合作玩 Minecraft 。游戏仍然会使用整个 GPU 来进行图形处理，因为 Copilot 运行在 NPU 上。

entry.title: OpenAI 和 Sam Altman 抄袭了斯嘉丽·约翰逊的声音，据说是使用了一位未透露姓名的声音相似的配音女演员
entry.content:
斯嘉丽约翰逊在向多家媒体发表的一份声明中：

去年九月，我收到了 Sam Altman 的录用通知，他想聘请我为当前的 ChatGPT 4.0 系统配音。他告诉我，他觉得通过我为系统发声，我可以弥合科技公司和创意人员之间的差距，并帮助消费者对人类和人工智能的巨大变化感到满意。他说他觉得我的声音会给人们带来安慰。

经过深思熟虑，出于个人原因，我拒绝了这个提议。九个月后，我的朋友、家人和公众都注意到名为“Sky”的最新系统听起来多么像我。

当我听到发布的演示时，我感到震惊、愤怒和难以置信，奥特曼先生会追求一种听起来与我如此相似的声音，以至于我最亲密的朋友和新闻媒体都无法区分。奥特曼先生甚至暗示这种相似性是故意的，他在推特上发了一个词“她”——指的是我为聊天系统萨曼莎配音的电影，她与人类建立了亲密的关系。

在 ChatGPT 4.0 演示版发布前两天，Altman 先生联系了我的经纪人，要求我重新考虑。在我们连接之前，系统就已经存在了。

太平洋时间昨晚 11:30， OpenAI 发推文：

我们听说过有关我们如何选择 ChatGPT 中的声音的问题，尤其是 Sky。我们正在努力暂停使用 Sky，同时解决这些问题。

他们“听到了问题”。

这符合人们对硅谷“科技兄弟”的各种不良刻板印象。我的意思是，如果他们从未联系过约翰逊，只是雇佣了一位听起来像她的女演员，在某种程度上，那是一回事。但要与她协商正式提供她的声音，并在她拒绝后继续提供类似的声音吗？一些选择：与他们合作或被敲诈。萨姆·奥尔特曼究竟是如何希望能够逃脱惩罚的呢？人们只能推测奥特曼期望约翰逊翻身，但他为什么会这样期望呢？她是好莱坞历史上票房收入最高的女演员，而好莱坞的才华并不以翻滚而闻名。尤其是约翰逊，她因挺身而出对抗财力雄厚的公司而享有盛誉。

此外，考虑到在 OpenAI 演示前两天，约翰逊关于 Altman 再次伸出援手的声明中夹杂着傲慢和花絮，有人真的相信这个“​​Sky”声音不是根据约翰逊本人的录音训练的吗？对于 OpenAI 来说最好的情况是，他们确实找到了一位声音相似的女演员，但整个故事有很强的“我今年夏天找到了一个女朋友，但她住在加拿大”的氛围。

entry.title: 人工智能的野心与碳中和目标
entry.content:
Justine Calma，为 The Verge 撰文：

与 2020 年做出大胆的气候承诺时相比，微软现在产生的地球供暖污染要多得多。其温室气体排放量实际上在 2023 财年增加了 30% 左右，这表明该公司要实现这一目标有多么困难气候目标，同时竞相成为人工智能领域的领导者。

训练和运行人工智能模型是一项日益消耗能源的工作，其对气候的影响才刚刚开始显现。微软最新的可持续发展报告是大型科技公司所面临难题的一个很好的案例研究，这些公司近年来做出了大量气候承诺，但当它们将重点转向人工智能时，最终可能会造成更多污染。

The Verge 的标题是“微软对人工智能的痴迷正在危及其气候野心”，我认为这正确地体现了微软的优先事项。我想知道对于苹果来说，问题是否发生了逆转，苹果对气候的痴迷是否正在危及他们的人工智能雄心？苹果公司在 2020 年宣布的到2030 年实现 100% 碳中和的目标没有丝毫退缩。当时，苹果汽车给我的印象是实现这一目标的最大障碍。现在他们已经取消了泰坦计划，这不是问题。但在我看来，人工智能是新的最大障碍——这是他们在 2020 年没有预见到的通配符行业变化。

entry.title: 传闻中的 2025 年新款超薄 iPhone 或许是 iPhone Pro 的补充，而不是取代
entry.content:
回复：我对 2025 年将推出更贵、更薄的 iPhone 17 机型的传闻的猜测，Ryan Jones 写道：

也许是第一次，我怀疑你已经离开了。

他们尝试了高端 iPhone X，效果很好。他们尝试了Mini，但销量不够。他们尝试了Plus，但销量不够。 Pro Max 成为最受欢迎的产品。

所以你会怎么做？

  • 将 Pro Max 做得更大（今年为 6.7 英寸 → 6.9 英寸）
  • 削减“额外”的非专业手机，更小不起作用，更大不起作用
  • 再次走上市场

因此：

  • iPhone 18（6.1英寸）
  • iPhone 18 Pro（6.1英寸）
  • iPhone 18 Pro Max（6.9 英寸）
  • iPhone“超”（6.7英寸）

哦，我非常喜欢这种思考。这符合苹果的历史战略。当他们尝试新事物但不受欢迎时，他们就会继续前进。 iPhone 5C 是一次性的——不再是色彩缤纷、“漂亮、毫无歉意的塑料”iPhone。 iPhone Mini 只使用了两年（iPhone 12 和 13），而这些传言表明 iPhone Plus 只会使用三年（iPhone 14、15 和今年即将推出的 16）。

但当 iPhone 机型大受欢迎时，苹果并不会将它们一扫而光。值得注意的是，革命性的 iPhone X 与绝对进化的iPhone 8 和 8 Plus 一起出现，这三款手机都配备了当时全新的 A11 Bionic 芯片。两年前，苹果将 Ultra 添加到 Apple Watch 系列中，但仅淘汰了传统手表的钛金属“Edition”型号。苹果可能会像琼斯建议的那样打造一款四款 iPhone，这是完全有道理的：保留常规尺寸的标准 iPhone，保留 Pro 和 Pro Max，并添加一款新的、比以往更薄、更强大的 iPhone。比以往任何时候都贵，“Ultra”型号位于顶部。进军高端市场是他们过去每次尝试的策略。如果他们销售 2000 美元以上的 iPad，为什么不销售 2000 美元以上的 iPhone？对于更多人来说，iPhone 比苹果生产的任何设备都更重要。

Spitball：那么，Apple 是如何将 iPhone 做得如此薄，就像新款 iPad Pro 一样，成为人们首先注意到该设备的地方呢？把后面的玻璃去掉怎么样？背面由铝或钛制成，可提高刚性、减轻重量并消除跌落时的故障点。这需要一种新的感应充电方法——所有高端手机（不仅仅是 iPhone）都采用玻璃后背的全部原因是感应 Qi 充电不能穿过金属。也许更像 MacBook 上的 MagSafe？

迄今为止最薄的 iPhone是2014 年的 iPhone 6 ，厚度为 6.9 毫米（不包括相机镜头）。

entry.title: iOS 17.5.1 修复了重新出现已删除照片的错误
entry.content:
MacRumors 引用了 Apple 自己的发行说明（在撰写本文时尚未发布到网络上）：

此更新提供了重要的错误修复，并解决了一个罕见的问题：数据库损坏的照片即使已被删除，也可能会重新出现在照片库中。

这是一个严重的错误，因此 17.5.1 在 17.5.0 发布一周后发布也就不足为奇了。

entry.summary: 我在 Twitter/X、Mastodon 和 Threads 上进行了同样的民意调查：“对苹果不再在新设备上添加贴纸以减少浪费的想法？”，有两个选项：👍 或 👎。
entry.content:
从本周的新款 iPad 开始，苹果不再在包装盒上贴上徽标贴纸，这或多或少地对环境问题表示了不满，因为我受到了一些读者的反对。

我的想法是，既然包装盒中包含了所有其他“文件”——保修信息、安全信息、快速入门指南——为什么不额外附上一张只是为了好玩呢？反对贴纸的一个论点是，即使只是多一张纸也会增加。如果这些贴纸的厚度为 0.1 毫米，那么 10 亿张贴纸的堆叠高度将达到 100 公里。但这仍然只是苹果公司在每个盒子中包含的许多其他纸张中的一张。

反对贴纸的更好论据是它们是塑料的。所有其他盒内文书都是实际的纸张，包装本身（包括内部结构）都是纸板。纸张和纸板是完全可回收的。多年来，苹果公司几乎消除了包装中的所有塑料，包括透明收缩包装。所以考虑一下我的想法改变了：去掉盒子上的贴纸，但在苹果零售店向那些想要它们的人提供它们，是一个很好的妥协。

我在 Twitter/X 、 Mastodon和Threads上进行了同样的民意调查：“对苹果不再在新设备上添加贴纸以减少浪费的想法？”，有两个选项：👍 或 👎。结果：

这种新方法在周二的主题演讲中几次出现的口号捕捉到了优雅的口号：让Google为您进行谷歌搜索。这是一个词，可以将浏览网络识别出来 - 一项任务曾经被认为是娱乐性的，以至于被昵称为“冲浪” - 这是一件繁琐的工作，还有更好的机器人。 [...]

这是一个敏锐的观察。网络网络的部分原因是它非常有趣。或至少是，应该是。人们现在发现这是一个琐事的想法不是对Google的谴责，而是网络本身的状态。

尽管如此，随着I/O的第一天结束，很难逃脱我们所知道的网络正在进入一种管理下的衰落的感觉。在过去的两十年中，Google扩展到了网络的许多不同部分，以至于它成为它的代名词。现在，LLMS承诺让用户了解网络实时所包含的所有内容，Google终于拥有完成工作所需的内容：以其自身的重要方式替换网络。

钱币。多么令人沮丧的视野。

entry.content:
苹果新闻编辑室：

Apple今天宣布了今年晚些时候将推出的新可访问性功能，包括眼睛跟踪，这是一种身体残障用户用眼睛控制iPad或iPhone的方式。此外，音乐触觉将为聋哑人或难以听见的用户提供一种新的方式，可以在iPhone中使用Taptic Engine体验音乐；声带快捷方式将允许用户通过制作自定义声音来执行任务；在移动车辆中使用iPhone或iPad时，车辆运动提示可以帮助减少疾病的运动； Visionos将出现更多的可访问性功能。这些功能结合了Apple硬件和软件的功能，利用Apple硅，人工智能和机器学习，以进一步进一步为每个人设计产品的长达数十年的承诺。

全球可及性意识日（明天）的时机已经变成了一个不错的传统：每年五月，苹果都在非正式地开始“ WWDC季节”，并发布了即将到来的可访问性功能的公告。

当米高梅度假村在9月遭受1亿美元的黑客攻击时， 首席执行官比尔·霍恩巴克（Bill Hornbuckle）并不担心收入损失，因为网络保险会涵盖标签。他开玩笑说：“我只能想象明年的账单将是什么。”

几周后，在与分析师的电话中，霍恩巴克（Hornbuckle） 抱怨过去几年的保险成本上升“惊人”。

这个故事整齐地说明了网络责任范围的危机。多年来，公司在安全保险方面的投资比实际安全性更多。结果是数据泄露的潮汐浪潮驱动了保费成本，以至于它们迅速变得无法承受。

一些大型企业正在通过创建自己的“圈养承运人”，即为其服务的保险提供商来回应增加的成本。但这显然不是小型企业的选择，而小型企业更有可能完全没有保险。

根据放大保险合作伙伴销售副总裁安德鲁·布奇（Andrew Bucci）的说法，“这将是某些人可能必须自我保险的地步，这意味着他们不会拿出网络政策，而他们只是交叉手指没有某种违规行为。”对于中小型企业来说，这是一场巨大的赌博，因为单个安全事件可能会破产。

在Kolide，我们已经看到我们的网络保险费在过去两年中增长了40％，我们很好奇：

  • 是什么推动了增加？
  • 谁真的需要网络安全保险？
  • 普通公司如何降低保费？

我们发现，保险公司本身可以通过对客户（例如MFA，端点安全和退休终止终止软件）的某些（基本）安全要求来帮助我们摆脱这一危机。

阅读完整的博客以了解有关我们发现的更多信息。

entry.summary: 通过变得更薄，更轻而不是更重的“ Pro”设备不是非seceitur。
entry.content:
对于iPad的整个生存的后半部分，产品审阅者的共识（包括您的真正审阅者）非常一致，尤其是在iPad Pros：令人难以置信的功能强大且美丽的硬件受到限制有限的软件时。这就是关于2022年2021年， 2020年和2018年的新iPad Pros的共识。实际上，共识可以说是一个词。我不确定所有技术中是否有任何产品一直被产品审阅者如此多年来如此多的产品。

令人难以置信的功能强大且美丽的硬件受到限制的软件的障碍物。

但是，如果我们想这错话怎么办？这个结论 - iPad Pros是由功能不足的软件放下的绝佳硬件 - 从硬件优先的角度开始。摘要，鉴于这种惊人的硬件，什么类型的软件应该为它供电？什么样的操作系统？ UI的什么隐喻？ iPad Pros一直以来 - 自iPad阵容中的Pro Fork首次亮相以来，Protable-workstation级计算机硬件。 iPados从来都不是工作站风格的操作系统。显而易见的事实 - 最近几周，欧盟对苹果公司声称iPad和iPhone是单独平台的说法，将Bullshit （或者也许是Conneries ）重申 - iPados是iOS面向平板电脑的变体。

这从来没有比现在更真实了 - 通过某些实用措施，M4 iPad Pro是苹果公司生产的最快计算机。但是，iPados并不是典型的电源用户认为在超功能硬件上运行的系统。

但是，让我们对此思考。与其从硬件开始并思考理想的软件要利用其功能的感觉，不如从软件开始。简单性优先型控制台式触摸屏平板电脑计算的概念。使用智能手机风格的护栏计算的隐喻，具有特定于平板电脑的功能，例如手写笔支持和笔记本电脑对接。平板电脑的操作系统毫不掩饰的iOS版本，而不是MacOS的剥离版本。 Apple应该构建哪种类型的硬件来实例化此类平台？

显然，苹果应该为大众市场建造负担得起的iPad：iPad非常薄，非常轻巧，显示屏非常出色，性能良好，电池寿命很好。最初的2010年iPad（仅提供一个9.7英寸）的入口价格为500美元。通货膨胀调整后，今天的价格超过700美元。新的11英寸M2 iPad Air的起价仅为600美元； 13英寸iPad Air的价格为800美元。非常不错的不可用的11英寸iPad（正式销售为10.9英寸）的价格仅为350美元，实际上是通货膨胀调整后的原始iPad价格的一半。

这些是出色的设备，可吸引价格符合优质（iPad）和更好 /更好 /最佳阵容中的更好（iPad Air）插槽。但是最好的呢？ Apple应该为愿意花费更多的iPados用户提供什么？

为了这一论点，让我们假设存在数以千计的人（也许是1亿个）喜欢iPad的用户。那些因其工作方式而感到有能力而不是障碍的人，并且对揭露MacOS或Windows（例如MacOS或Windows）复杂性的计算机没有或很少需要的人。而且，还有数千万人喜欢拥有iPad来补充而不是更换台式计算机的人。在广泛的笔触中存在两种类型的iPad用户：（a）那些iPados（iPados）适合其主要“大屏幕”个人计算机； （b）那些iPad由于其非常有意的计算型限制，而iPad只能是Mac，Windows或Linux“真实”计算机的补充设备。这两个组都不需要更强大的iPad，因此，因此，每个人（Power-use-user nerds and Completic用户）都倾向于使用iPad，直到他们破裂，磨损或在软件支持中衰老。

就个人而言，我直接落入（b）组。我感到严重陷入困境，试图在日常工作中使用任何iPad。我的个人iPad是2018年的11英寸iPad Pro，即使在上周花了最后一周测试了这款新的13英寸M4 iPad Pro之后，它仍然对我的需求非常好。因此，使用权力的人的思考是，如果我对这6岁的硬件很好，而这是由这一新的M4 iPad Pros吹走的，那么，IPSO事实上，某些事情是深刻而根本的软件平台错误。如果应该使用iPados软件平台，它将迫使用户 - 像我一样，也许像您一样 - 升级到最新，最出色的硬件，以“利用”硬件的非凡功能。

但是，如果这被误导了怎么办？如果iPados平台很棒，该怎么办？或者至少，该软件非常接近它应该是什么以及应该如何工作的标记？那么，Apple应该将其硬件工程资源应用于iPad系列中的最佳层次？

在这种情况下，苹果将优先考虑诸如优化硬件以稀薄和轻巧，同时保持较长的电池寿命。在这些目的中，他们将在苹果硅的每瓦性能上进行非凡的性能并不是要使速度更快，而是要使iPad的所有功能更加有效。相同能耗的速度是MAC思维方式的两倍。一半的能耗是iOS的思维方式。但是这些是每瓦硬币相同性能的两个方面。

从这个角度来看，从Better （iPad Air）到Best （iPad Pro）不应与功率和性能有关，并且能够将设备用于任何且所有复杂的计算任务，而是要变得更加明显。就像从丰田到雷克萨斯一样。

展示

对于从根本上是全屏幕的设备，这意味着可以使最佳的显示屏显示。每个iPad Apple制作的每个iPad都有一个不错的（时间）显示。每个iPad Pro都有很好的显示。但是还有太大的完善空间。

考虑打印机。在我的一生中，我从粗糙，痛苦，令人讨厌的点 - 摩托克打印机，喷墨到300 dpi黑白激光打印机到600 dpi激光打印机，再到1200 dpi color Laser激光打印机。在长达数十年的时代，印刷是大多数人计算机生活的重要组成部分，产出的质量稳步提高。没有人需要更高质量的输出，但是更好。

显示技术很可能有一个终点，在这种技术中，平板电脑大小的显示器非常好，以至于没有任何意义改善它们。在我看来，打印机已经到了十年前就到了。 1但是我们还没有到达，苹果的脚似乎是踏板到金属的推动iPad Pro展示质量的前进。

关于这个新的串联OLED“ Ultra Retina XDR” iPad Pro Display的所有内容都非常出色。黑人是黑色的，白色是白色的，一切都比我的中年眼睛辨别得多。哦，很明亮。它是如此明亮，以至于在晚上在床上读书时，与一个尝试垂涎的配偶一起，我不得不将亮度转向控制中心。它是如此明亮，以至于在阳光直射的户外似乎非常可用。

没有人真的需要在iPad上显示这么好。但是大多数人肯定会喜欢在iPad上拥有如此好的屏幕。其中一些很乐意为此支付溢价。

表现

我的评论单元是1 TB型号，具有10个CPU内核和16 GB RAM。这是Geekbench 6的基准（得分较高）：

单身的多图形处理器
M4 iPad Pro（2024） 3,780 14,616 53,555
M2 iPad Pro（2022） 2,627 9,987 46,643
M2 MacBook Air（2022） 2,631 9,997 46,486
M3 MacBook Air（2024） 3,092 人12,036 47,785

所有设备都有13英寸的显示屏。运行iPados的iPad 17.5。 Macs运行MACOS 14.5。所有分数在3次中平均。

没有带有M3芯片的iPad模型，我怀疑永远不会有一个。因此，我选择了上表中的四个设备，以推测假设的M3 iPad的执行方式。 iPados和macOS是非常不同的OS，但是M2 iPad Pro和M2 MacBook Air的Geekbench 6结果不仅接近，而且实际上相同。据推测，如果存在M3 iPad Pro，它的Geekbench得分将与M3 MacBook Air的分数几乎相同。

我不知道Geekbench是否是进行此类评估的好基准，但是如果是，无论是在iPad还是MacBook中，M3似乎都比M2快1.2倍，这两个单曲中的M3均约为1.2倍。 - 和多核性能，在单核和多核中，M4比M3快约1.2倍。 Geekbench的得分仅提高了约1.1×从M1到M2。但是，如果我们可以期望每次连续的M系列生成〜1.2×改进，则M6将提供M2的CPU性能两倍，而M8三倍。 （由于英特尔学会了艰难的方式，因此假设可以维持每一代1.2倍改进是一个很大的“如果”。）

我还将包括速度计3.0的结果，这是Web渲染引擎的基准测试（得分更好）：

这些结果对我来说没有多大意义。 M2 iPad Pro和M2 MacBook Air的性能几乎相同，但是M3 MacBook Air比M4 iPad Pro快得多，尽管上述Geekbench结果表明M4应该比M3快1.2倍。我认为这种差异并不值得使我们的大脑陷入困境。我怀疑这更多是关于iPados和MacOS版本的Safari/Webkit之间的差异。

最重要的是，M4非常快，根据Apple的规定规格和我自己的观察，使用了一周的时间，非常有效。看来苹果没有发挥营销技巧，尽管M3之后仅六个月左右，M4还是值得下一代名称。

这使我们思考了一个事实，即M4比两个月前击中MacBook Air系列的M3更好。那不是理想的，但这就是事实。理想情况下，新的MacBook Airs也将拥有M4。苹果没有，几乎肯定不会完全解释这背后的理由，但是您不必成为莫里斯·张即可推测这与TSMC的生产能力有关。 MacBook Airs是苹果最畅销的笔记本电脑。 iPad Pros是苹果最畅销的iPad。我认为这很简单：当前的MacBook Air具有M3，而不是M4，因为尚无足够的M4芯片供应满足对MacBook Airs的需求。 M4供应显然足以满足iPad Pro的需求，此外，根据Apple的说法，只有M4能够驱动超视网膜XDR显示器，这些显示实际上是两个OLED显示器相互堆叠的OLED显示器。

因此，我认为今天的MacBook Air无法使用M4，因为TSMC还不能在其第二代3NM过程中生产出足够的M4芯片。相反，今天的新iPad Pros无法使用M3，因为M3缺少可以驱动串联的OLED Ultra Retina XDR显示器的显示控制器 - 此外，我怀疑，这些新iPad Pros的非凡薄和低重量不会没有M4比M3的热优势，这是很有可能的。苹果可以使用M3制作薄iPad Pros，但iPad Pros却不是这种薄而轻的。

“ Pro”的含义

这使我们回到了iPad Pro应该是什么的整个问题。很容易说它们都是计算机。从理论上讲，MacBook可以运行iPados。理论上可以运行iPad。 （在2020年宣布Mac的Apple Silicon过渡后，苹果公司提供的开发商套件实际上是Mac Mini底盘的iPad Pro 。）

如果我每次听到有人宣布苹果应该“只是”向MacOS添加触摸屏的支持，并允许iPad在MacOS和iPados之间进行双启动，那么明天我将成为银行的一个非常烦人的客户。那些拥护这种意见的人通常如此坚决，以至于这种安排对用户来说既是一个好主意，又是“容易”的苹果，以至于他们坚信苹果为什么不这样做的唯一可能的解释是将iPad和MacBook出售给可能只需要一个的用户的计划的所有部分。

从完全不同的角度来看，苹果清楚地看到了这两个平台。当然，不可否认的是，苹果公司从事销售设备的业务。但是，苹果故意障碍iPad以销售更多MacBook的想法没有长期意义。苹果蓬勃发展，只有在使最佳设备成为可能的情况下才能真正成功。如果iPados从根本上不足，为什么Apple卖出这么多iPad？为什么这么多iPad用户对他们的iPad如此满意，除了手机以外的唯一计算机？ “我想以iPados不支持的方式工作”并不意味着“每个人都想以iPados不支持的方式工作”。

我多次观察到苹果以多种方式使用了形容词Pro 。有时意味着专业，但有时只是豪华。 iPad和MacBook阵容说明了这种差异。使用MacBooks，Pro模型更加专业。他们的显示屏更好，扬声器更好，是的，但是主要是要更快地做事。它们比MacBook Airs厚更重。 iPad Pros采取的方式相反：它们比iPad Air更薄，更轻。是的，具有讽刺意味的是，使用iPad，“空气”模型既不是最薄也不是最轻的。但这确实解释了苹果在iPad和Mac平台之间看到的哲学差异。更好的Mac更快。也很好，但主要更快。更好的iPad更好。也更快，但主要更好。这些新的iPad Pros非常好。优化对善良的优化被低估了。

我已经看到了“ iPados限制的惊人硬件”人群的建议，每个喜欢甚至使用iPad的人都应该适应iPad Air甚至只是纯粹的iPad。 iPad Pro的权力将浪费，因此没有感觉为其支付高价。但是，将这种权力放在不一定要客观地衡量的方式中使用该功能是如何浪费的呢？新的iPad Pros Sport M4不仅是为了完成更强大的任务，而且主要是为了使日常任务尽可能地完成，首先要简单地将iPad Pro掌握在手上。

新的魔术键盘

就像我的意愿一样，我使用新的魔术键盘使用了M4 iPad Pro本身编写了整个评论。 2这个新的魔术键盘是多么神话般的升级。触控板更大，不可否认地更好。铝棕榈休息感觉更好。钥匙具有出色的打字感觉 - 我认为比旧魔术键盘的感觉更好，但肯定不会更糟。

因此，新的魔术键盘提供了更坚固的结构，更好的打字感觉，更好，更大的触控板，它们添加了功能钥匙行，并配有左上角ESC键。

新的魔术键盘比旧的键盘轻约5％。奇怪的是，苹果没有将重量列为魔术键盘的规格，但是根据我的规模，原始的13英寸魔术键盘重约700克；新的重量约为660克。

一些权重，iPad包裹在相应的魔法键盘中（所有这些都以我的比例来衡量）：

  • 13英寸M3 MacBook Air：1,227g
  • 13英寸M4 iPad Pro：1,247g
  • 13英寸M2 iPad Pro：1,398g
  • 14英寸M3 Max MacBook Pro：1,607g

到目前为止，比带有魔术键盘的13英寸iPad Pro（约12％）的13英寸MacBook Air轻170克。但是，现在，带有魔术键盘的13英寸iPad Pro仅比MacBook Air重20G。那是一件事。您绝对可以感觉到手头上的差异。

我对新的魔术键盘有一个重要的抱怨：很难打开。 MacBook在触控板下面有一个从铝制底座上雕刻出来的凹口。关闭后，此缺口使您的拇指一个开始在显示屏上施加向上压力以将其打开的地方。新的魔术键盘上没有这样的缺口。因此，我发现自己没有提起“显示”（实际上是iPad本身）将其打开到笔记本电脑配置中，而是从垂直于桌子的iPad Pro开始，然后将键盘/触控板向下拉下来。您本身不必撬开它，但是键盘盒中iPad的最重型本质上的最高本质使得比带有轻巧显示上衣的MacBook更难打开。最高的还要求魔术键盘铰链比任何MacBook铰链都更加僵硬。这是野兽的本质。原始魔术键盘中的iPad也不容易打开。

各种各样的

  • 新的铅笔专家感觉就像是铅笔2，但带有触觉反馈的“挤压”动作。就像Apple最近的触控板（包括新魔术键盘上的触控板）一样，Pencil Pro确实没有单击按钮。它是伪造的。但是，伪造件是如此令人信服，以至于它与实际的单击按钮没有区别。我什至都不是插图画家或素描师，所以我不能声称在上周将铅笔专业人士放在其步调上。但是，用于在铅笔工具之间切换的新工具切换径向菜单的聪明是如此有趣，以至于我希望我对铅笔有更多的用途，而不是注释PDF文档。真的很棒，而且铅笔专业人士也与新的M2 iPad Airs一起使用也很棒。

  • 电池寿命非常好。当我键入此句子时，我一直在使用iPad Pro不停地使用数小时，并且电池仍为83％。

  • 将前置摄像头移至长边，优化用于笔记本电脑方向，这是显而易见的胜利。我继续认为，苹果几年前没有触发这种变化，这有点奇怪，当时他们首先接受了许多人希望在笔记本电脑式键盘盒中使用iPad的事实。但是有一个缺点：面部ID传感器与相机相同的传感器阵列，当将iPad Pro作为平板电脑持有平板电脑时，在肖像方向上，这就是我的右手经常的位置。不过，我已经习惯了一周的变化，但是 - 我遇到了“嘿，您的手阻止了面部ID传感器”动画箭头警告的最初几天比最近的几天更频繁。

  • 我的评论单位硬件是黑色的，我认为这看起来很棒。

  • 新iPad Pros的显着薄度 - 我一直在测试的13英寸型号厚度仅为5.1mm； 11英寸型号5.3mm - 提出了有关耐用性的问题。它会弯曲吗？手头感觉很坚固，没有弯曲。我向Apple的代表询问了耐久性，他们声称新的iPad Pros应该证明，每一位都像以前的iPad Pro一样耐用（尤其是抗弯曲）。 Arun“ Mr Whosetheboss ” Maini Maini对我做得更好，并在发表在Twitter/X的相机上采访中询问了John Ternus的耐用性。 Ternus的答案回应了我在背景上被告知的内容：新的iPad Pros拥有其主逻辑板，并且在肖像模式下的硬件中间沿着硬件中间运行的肋骨。这种设计既可以更好地散发热量，又增加了底盘的刚度。耐用性问题只能通过广泛的现实使用才能真正得到回答，但是我的钱是在这些新的iPad Pros上的耐用性。

  • 前后相机都很好。没有狂欢，但没有抱怨。上一代iPad Pros具有1×（“宽”）和0.5×（“ Ultra wide”）摄像机，M4型号又回到了唯一的1倍，这有点奇怪，但这似乎不像是一个回归，更像是在上一代中添加超宽相机的标志是过度的。麦克风似乎是内置在平板电脑中的麦克风。

  • 我的评论单元没有纳米文本显示效果。如果我购买其中一个iPad，我可能会选择纳米文本，但是我很想知道确实测试了它的评论者。 （我很好奇，本周再次在Apple商店亲自看到它。）

结论

iPados就是它。无论您（或我）认为它是一个生产力平台，如果您认为这不是许多人所爱的，那您都是傻瓜。 It's popular, even for some “professional” use cases, not despite iPadOS's guardrails but often because of them. Those guardrails feel limiting to me ,often very much so , but those same guardrails are liberating to others. There is tremendous power in having a computer that is simple not merely by suggestion but by hard and fast technical constraints.

Should you only buy what you need, or splurge for what you'd most enjoy? A Lexus instead of a Toyota. A first-class seat instead of coach. Craft IPA instead of Budweiser. In other aspects of life, few question the mere existence of premium-priced superior experiences. But with the iPad, those unsatisfied by the nature of iPadOS seem to think those who do love iPadOS don't deserve a premium tier of hardware.

And there are professional apps used for serious work on iPads. Apple's own Final Cut and Logic for iPads are not toys. Both are very serious siblings — and for non-extreme projects, peers — to their respective Mac versions. For visual artists there are a plethora of serious iPad apps: DaVinci Resolve (video color grading), ZBrush (3D sculpting), Procreate Dreams , Affinity Designer , Frame IO . There's even a paint app from Adobe called Photoshop , which apparently has been around for a while. Arguing that “no one can do real work on an iPad” reminds me of Yogi Berra's “No one goes there anymore, it's too crowded.”

A “pro” device that goes pro by getting thinner and lighter, not heavier and thicker, is not a non sequitur. Or at least not necessarily. What makes for a better iPad is simply orthogonal, in many regards, to what makes for a better Mac. Way back in 2010, when the iPad was new (and ran what was called iOS) and it felt like the Mac's days might be winding down, I wrote , “It's the heaviness of the Mac that allows iOS to remain light.” I meant that figuratively. But these new M4 iPad Pros make it quite literal.

entry.title: The Sound of Software
entry.content:
Andy Allen and Thomas Williams, from Not Boring:

Sound is an outcast in Software Design. We may embrace the aesthetics of animation and visuals, but sound is different. It's intrusive. Unlike visuals on a screen, you can't look away or ignore it. It's enough to make you rip the batteries out of a toy or frisbee an iPad across the room (speaking from experience).

And yet, play a video game without sound and its powerful punch lands with no force. Without music, once moving moments in a film become dull, even comical (Jurassic Park, Rocky). Sound holds an immense power to elevate any experience — including the most boring of software.

Sound in software isn't inherently bad. It's just been really badly designed.

We use sound in every !Boring app, and many have called it out as one of their favorite aspects of our apps. We've learned a few things about when to use sound, how to design it, and how to implement it. When done right, sound unlocks a path to much richer software experiences.

entry.title: Pointless NYT Report Says Apple Plans to Improve Siri
entry.content:
The Times sent me a news alert for this story — under the three-way byline of Tripp Mickle, Brian X. Chen, and Cade Metz — but I don't think there's a single sentence of news in the entire thing. The gist of it is that Apple recognizes that ChatGPT makes Siri look even dumber than it did before and that they plan to use LLM technology to improve it.就是这样。

Determined to catch up in the tech industry's AI race, Apple has made generative AI a tent pole project — the company's special, internal label that it uses to organize employees around once-in-a-decade initiatives.

This is niggling, I know, but if “tent pole projects” only come once per decade at Apple, that means, by the Times's count, there have only been 4 or 5 since the Macintosh debuted 40 years ago.

The truth is that in Apple lingo, tentpole is used to describe features, not projects, and they aim to ship around three or four tentpole features in every major release. The tentpole features are the ones that get the most time in keynotes. It'd be flabbergasting, given the current state of the tech world and Apple's teasers , if a much-improved LLM-based Siri were not one of the tentpole features announced at WWDC next month.

( Bonus usage note: New Oxford American — the dictionary Apple licenses to include with MacOS and iOS — has the term as two words , “tent pole”, and thus hyphenated when used as a modifier. But Merriam-Webster closes it up , both as a noun and adjective. The Times isn't nearly the bastion of consistency and quality that it once was, and, having dismantled its once-legendary copy desk 7 years ago , you'll be unsurprised to know that in other recent articles tentpole has appeared in closed-up form.)

entry.summary: New iPad Pros and iPad Airs.
entry.content:
Keynote / Mini Events

Apple hosted about 50 members of the media in New York City, in their ludicrously spacious Tribeca townhouse, to watch the keynote stream live. They had a hands-on area post-keynote, and a bunch of demos and briefings throughout the morning and early afternoon.很不错。 More low-key than the pre-COVID on-stage events (like the Brooklyn one in 2018, when they introduced the first retina MacBook Air and the 2018 iPad Pros ), but low-key is good. Doing things in-person is good. (They held a similar event yesterday in London , too — which perhaps explains why they streamed the keynote at 7am PT.)

The New iPad Airs

No surprises here, but the big news is the addition of a 13-inch iPad Air to the lineup. Until last summer Apple's only “big” MacBook was the 16-inch MacBook Pro (which starts at $2,500), and their only “big” iPad was the 13-inch iPad Pro (which, until yesterday, started at $1,100). If you wanted a big-screen MacBook or iPad you had to pay premium Pro prices, even if you didn't need Pro features or performance. Last summer they introduced the 15-inch MacBook Air (starting price: $1,300) and now there's the 13-inch iPad Air (starting price: $800).

There's really not much else to say about the new iPad Airs. During the keynote, John Ternus described the iPad Air as getting features and components that were previously exclusive to the iPad Pro models, and that's apt. But that means there's not much new to talk about.

The New M4 iPad Pros

They are thin — really thin. It seems impossible that the new iPad Pros are thinner than an iPod Nano, but read the tech specs and weep:

  • 7th-gen iPod Nano : 5.4mm
  • M4 iPad Pro 11″ : 5.3mm
  • M4 iPad Pro 13″ : 5.1mm

For completeness:

  • M2 iPad Air 11″ : 6.1mm
  • M2 iPad Air 13″ : 6.1mm
  • iPad Mini 6th-gen : 6.3mm
  • iPad 10th-gen : 7.0mm

The thinness is noticeable in hand, but the reduction in weight is even more noticeable. Per Apple's specs, the new 13-inch iPad Pro weighs 579g, down from 682g in the 2022 models. That's a sounds-too-good-to-be-true 15 percent reduction. The weight reduction for the 11-inch iPad Pros is less dramatic: 444g, down from 466g in the previous generation. (Those are Wi-Fi-only weights, but cellular networking adds only a meager 3–4g.)

Apple is advertising the new tandem OLED “Ultra Retina XDR” displays as “ the world's best displays ”, full stop. From what I saw in the hands-on area yesterday, they indeed look terrific: bright, inky-black blacks (as you'd expect from any OLED displays), seemingly no problems with blooming or a halo effect . Generally though, Apple's “best display” goes into the iPhone Pro, so purely as a guess, I'll bet that the iPhone 16 Pro models get this display technology come September.

And, yes, the new iPad Pros have the M4, not the M3 chips that debuted just six months ago. This seems largely driven by moving to TSMC's next-generation 3nm process, which brings efficiency gains compared to the first-generation 3nm process used to fabricate the A17 Pro and M3 family. In briefings yesterday, Apple reps emphasized, repeatedly, that these new iPad Pros could not have been built without the M4. The efficiency gains allowed Apple to make them remarkably thin and light, and more essentially, only the M4 has a display engine that can drive the new tandem OLED displays. This truly is one of those examples where Apple controlling the entire stack — their own silicon driving their own display design — puts their products in a league of their own. They couldn't drive the new displays without the M4's display controller and they wouldn't have engineered that display controller if they hadn't had these tandem OLED displays in mind.

Mark Gurman's week-before scoop that these iPads might have the M4 is simply remarkable, even with the hedging around “might”. A hall of fame rumor scoop. Nobody else even spitballed such a notion. If not for Gurman it would have been a rather shocking surprise in the keynote. And my understanding is that Apple went to extraordinary lengths during development of these iPad Pros to keep the debut of the M4 under wraps. Apple folks are never ever happy about leaks, but this one in particular seemingly surprised them. But it also makes me wonder about reports — most prominently by Gurman himself — that these iPads were originally slated to launch in March, presumably just a few weeks after the launch of the M3 MacBook Airs, and just two months after the launch of the Vision Pro, which sports an M2. How soon after the launch of the M3 could the M4 have appeared? One thing I'm taking away from this is that it's wrong to think about M-series generations as year-over-year annual iterations, like the A-series chips in iPhones. Rather, it seems like Apple is evolving the M-series chips in parallel, designing them with very specific but widely varied products in mind.

The iPad Family Lineup

Back in October, after Apple launched the Apple Pencil with USB-C, I wrote the following regarding the complexity and confusion in the iPad lineup :

Off the top of my head, what I'd like from Apple on the iPad front next year:

  • Drop the old 9th-gen iPad from the lineup. That iPad is so old it still has a home button.
  • Lower the price of the 10th-gen iPad by $100. (And maybe give it a speed bump from the A14 to A15 chip? But it's probably wishful thinking to hope for a price cut and a newer chip.)
  • Update the iPad Air (and Mini?) models to be more like today's iPad Pros, with Face ID instead of Touch ID.
  • Major revision of the iPad Pros, which haven't seen a major form factor change since 2018. Put more pro in the iPad Pros, just like Apple has done with the iPhone 15 Pro models.
  • Update the Magic Keyboard, ideally in a way that continues to support both iPad Airs and 11-inch iPad Pros. The Magic Keyboard is a great idea, and I think a popular one. But it ought to be better — thinner, lighter, and more durable. (The white ones especially age quickly. Keep your eyes out for them in the wild, in cafes and airports — they often look quite grungy. Compare and contrast with MacBooks, which often look great even after years of daily use.) Mark Gurman has reported that just such a revision to the Magic Keyboard is in the works.

That would clarify the iPad's three tiers: good (regular iPad, 10th-gen), better (iPad Air — the best choice for most people), and best (iPad Pros, with advanced new features and capabilities). The point should be to make the question “ Which iPad should I buy? ” as easy to answer as possible. I think Apple has made that question pretty easy to answer for iPhones, MacBooks, and Watches — and for peripherals like AirPods. Now do it for iPads.

Apple came pretty close to hitting every single item on my list yesterday. The only miss is that the new iPad Airs still use Touch ID, not Face ID. A few sources told me, after I wrote the above post in October, that Face ID components remain surprisingly expensive lo these many years after Face ID first appeared with the iPhone X in 2017, so I'm not surprised in the least that the iPad Airs still use Touch ID on the top button.

The only sore thumb in the entire iPad lineup is the iPad Mini, which, since it first appeared, has always been the least-frequently updated iPad. Compared to the 10th-gen regular-sized iPad, the iPad Mini seems expensive at $500. But the iPad Mini is more like a small iPad Air, with features like P3 wide color and an antireflective coating. And the current iPad Mini , despite being 2.5 years old, still has a faster chip than the 10th-gen iPad (A15 vs. A14).

A 13-inch M4 iPad Pro with 2 TB of storage, cellular networking, and the nano-texture display costs a cool $2,600.

Rounding up to 13

Praise Jeebus, Apple has decided to label the bigger iPads as “13-inch” rather than the more exact but far less graceful “12.9-inch”. Apple is more comfortable rounding down than up. Underpromise, overdeliver. Look at the tech specs for the 13-inch MacBook Air : the display is 13.6 inches, so it could credibly be rounded up to 14. But these product names are more like “size classes”, not specs. I've been referring to big iPad Pros as “13-inch” for a while now, on the same grounds as rounding up prices like $499 to $500. Glad to see Apple make it official though.

Pencil Proliferation

With yesterday's introduction of the Apple Pencil Pro, Apple now has made, and continues to sell, four different Pencil models. I saw a lot of gripes yesterday that this is confusing — that there ought to be just one Pencil, or perhaps two at the most. But in practice I don't think it's all that confusing. You don't start by buying a Pencil; you start by choosing an iPad, and then you buy a Pencil that goes with that iPad. Arguing that it's confusing that different iPads support different Pencils is like saying it's confusing that different iPhones require different cases. In real life you just buy a case that is designed for your specific phone model, and it's not confusing at all that the Apple Store carries cases for several generations of iPhone models, each in two different sizes.

I mean in theory, it would be better if there were one Pencil that worked with all iPads. And it stinks that if you have a Pencil 2 already, you can't use it with a new iPad Pro or Air. But the mistake that prevents Apple from being able to offer just one Pencil has nothing to do with any of the Pencil models, but instead was the company's yearslong resistance to moving the front-facing camera on iPads from the short side (like an iPhone) to the long side (like a laptop).

From my brief hands-on time, the haptic feedback and new squeeze gesture on the new Pencil Pro are just great. And for illustrators and calligraphers, the support for rotating the barrel to rotate the on-screen pen nib is very cool. On the cusp of the keynote I offhandedly hoped for the ability to turn the new Pencil upside down to get the eraser tool, but this squeeze gesture and the new radial menu of Pencil tools that appears contextually under the current pen location is a better idea. Upside down eraser support would offer a shortcut for just one tool; the squeeze menu gives you a shortcut to all tools.

I suspect naming the new Pencil “Pencil Pro” is a downstream effect of the fact that Apple needs to keep selling the Pencil 2. (People who own years-old iPads still buy new Pencils.) But Apple never printed the “2” on the Pencil 2 barrel — it just says “ Pencil”. And physically, the new Pencil Pro is indistinguishable from the Pencil 2 — same size, same color, same texture. They even use the same replacement tips. So if they had named it “Pencil 3” but still printed only “ Pencil” on the barrel, anyone who owned both models wouldn't be able to tell them apart. So “ Pencil Pro” it is, even though it works with the new non-pro iPad Airs.

Also: the new Pencil Pro supports Find My. Unsurprising, but nice.

各种各样的

  • Anyone playing a drinking game that required taking a shot for each mention of “AI” or “machine learning” during the keynote probably passed out before it ended.

  • There's just one rear-facing camera on the new iPad Pros. The previous generation had two: wide (1×) and ultra-wide (0.5×). I'm not sure what to make of that other than conceding that iPads don't really need multiple cameras. I can't recall ever — not even once — wishing that my personal iPad Pro from 2018 had an ultra-wide lens in addition to the main 1× camera. Perhaps this omission helped Apple shrink the camera bump on the new iPad Pros, and/or reduce the overall thickness?

  • Apple is, for the first time, offering a nano-texture display option for the new iPad Pros. It costs an additional $100 and is only offered with the 1 and 2 TB storage configurations. I liked the way it looked in my limited hands-on time yesterday, and it didn't seem problematic fingerprint-wise. I did not get the chance to try the nano-texture display with a Pencil, alas, but I can't help but suspect it offers an at least slightly more paper-like feel. One oddity: only the display has the texture — the black bezel surrounding the display is glossy. The delineation between the glossy bezel and textured display area is both easy to see and easy to feel. In a sunny room with glare from the windows, I thought that looked odd: obvious reflections and glare on the bezel, but no reflections or glare on the display content area. With the nano-texture versions of the Pro Display XDR and Studio Display, the nano-texture finish includes the bezel area — except for one tiny glossy spot on the Studio Display in front of the FaceTime camera lens. Perhaps with all the various sensors for Face ID and the front-facing camera, leaving the entire bezel glossy was deemed a better trade-off than making several glossy cutouts. (No notch on iPads.)

  • Apple is doing some chip-binning with the iPad Pros. The 256 and 512 GB models have 9-core CPUs (3 performance, 6 efficiency) and 8 GB of RAM. The 1 and 2 TB models have 10-core CPUs (4 performance, 6 efficiency) and 16 GB of RAM. (The new iPad Airs all have the same M2 chip with 8 GB of RAM.)

  • I still have no idea how the event name “Let Loose” is applicable to any of yesterday's announcements. But sometimes a name is just a name.

;
entry.title: ★ Brief Thoughts and Observations on Yesterday's 'Let Loose' iPad Keynote

entry.summary: It's downright bizarre to think that come this fall, all iPhone 16 models will sport as much RAM as base model Macs.
entry.content:
Following up on (a) my post earlier this week regarding on-device LLM features being RAM-hungry , and (b) my post regarding Mark Gurman's claim that M4 Macs will start shipping late this year , I will direct your attention to a report from MacRumors back in January that all iPhone 16 models will include 8 GB of RAM . With the iPhone 15 models, the non-pro models have 6 GB and the Pro models 8 GB . If true, one incongruity will be that new iPhones will have the same amount of RAM as most base-model Macs.

This came up on the most recent episode of ATP , and their show notes include these two charts posted to Mastodon by David Schaub, showing (a) the base RAM for all-in-one Mac desktops from 1984 onward; and (b) the base RAM in consumer Mac laptops from 1999 onward. It has always been the case that Apple has been open to criticism for base-model RAM being “one click” too low. Eg when base RAM was 1 GB, it should have been 2 GB; when it was 2 GB it should have been 4 GB; etc. But it was also always the case that Apple increased the base RAM every two years or so.不再。 iMacs have been stuck at 8 GB of base RAM since the 27-inch iMac from late 2012 . MacBook Airs have been stuck at 8 GB base RAM since 2017 .

I do think it's true that Apple silicon changed this equation. Perhaps even, as a rule of thumb, by a factor of 2 — that an Apple silicon Mac with 8 GB RAM performs as well under memory constraints as an Intel-based Mac with 16 GB. But base model consumer Macs have been stuck at 8 GB for a long time, and it's impossible to look at Schaub's charts and not see that regular increases in base RAM effectively stopped when Tim Cook took over as CEO. Apple silicon efficiency notwithstanding, more RAM is better, and certainly more future-proof. And it's downright bizarre to think that come this fall, all iPhone 16 models will sport as much RAM as base model Macs. (Supercomputer pioneer Seymour Cray on virtual memory : “Memory is like an orgasm. It's a lot better if you don't have to fake it.”)

entry.title: ★ Base-Model RAM in Apple Devices

entry.summary: “*The entire Mac product line is set for annual speed-bump Apple silicon updates*” is, as far I can tell, the actual story. Not “*Mac sales are in the tank and Apple is overhauling the whole product line to change its focus to AI.*”
entry.content:
Here's how I see the current state of Apple's Macintosh hardware lineup, three-and-a-half years into the Apple silicon era and midway through the M3 generation. Apple is a company that in many ways is built around an annual schedule. WWDC comes every June. New iPhones (along with Watches) come every September. The new OS releases (which are announced and previewed at WWDC) ship later each year in the fall. Many Apple products are not on an annual schedule — such as the iPad, to name the most prominent example — but the OSes are, and the iPhones and Watches are. All things considered, I think Apple would like to have more of its products on an annual cycle. This predictable regularity is one of the hallmarks of Tim Cook's era as CEO.

Launching a new PC architecture is difficult (to say the least). And the M1 launched at the end of 2020, the most tumultuous and disruptive year for the world since World War II. Then, M2 models seemed late — that's the only logical explanation for the M2 MacBook Pros not shipping until January 2023 , but their M3 successors shipping just 10 months later . Just last month Apple shipped the M3 MacBook Airs. It feels to me, as a longtime observer of the company, that with the M3 generation, Apple has started to hit its intended stride. The M1 and M2 generations were like an airplane taking off — a bit rocky and rough. Turbulence is to be expected. But with the M3, Apple silicon hit cruising altitude. The seatbelt light is now off, and new M-series chips are seemingly being developed on the same annual schedule as the iPhone's A-series chips. (Note that the M3 family uses the same 3nm fabrication process as the A17 Pro .)

If Apple wants to refresh Macs with new generations of M-series chips annually — and I suspect they do — the schedule we're seeing with the M3 generation makes sense: MacBook Pros in the fall, MacBooks Airs a few months later, pro desktops在春天。 Last year the M3 update to the iMac — a product that skipped the entire M2 generation — shipped alongside the MacBook Pros, but I could see that happening alongside the consumer MacBook Airs in future years. Because the iMacs skipped the M2 generation, they were overdue. That leaves the spring or even early summer for the high-performance Mac Studio and Mac Pro, and the surprisingly-pro-in-many-use-cases Mac Mini.

So I expect we'll see M3-generation updates to the Mac Studio, Mac Pro, and Mac Mini either in May (alongside the universally-expected lineup of new iPads) or (more likely) at WWDC in June. And then, if all things go according to Apple's plans, I expect to see M4-generation MacBook Pros in November, M4 MacBook Airs next February or March, and the desktop models just before or at WWDC 2025, 14 months from now. Lather, rinse, repeat, every 12 months for years to come.

And how do we expect the M4 chips to evolve? Everything tends to get incrementally faster between generations: CPU, GPU, I/O, Neural Engine. But it's the GPU where Apple silicon lags Nvidia's state-of-the-art in sheer performance, and it's GPU performance that's essential for AI model training (although serious training work takes place on server farms, not personal devices), so it's natural to expect GPU improvements to be an area of focus. Intel-based Mac Pros were configurable with up to 1.5 TB of RAM, but the M2 Ultra Mac Pro maxes out at 192 GB of RAM. Increasing the maximum amount of RAM in high-end configurations is an obvious improvement that Apple's chip designers should be focused on. So we'll probably see incremental (15 percent-ish) gains in CPU performance, greater gains in GPU and Neural Engine performance, and perhaps higher capacity for RAM.

No need to follow the rumor mill or to hear any leaks from insiders in Cupertino. The above summary can all be gleaned just by paying attention to Apple's patterns and industry-wide trends.

That brings us to a report by Mark Gurman at Bloomberg last week: “ Apple Plans to Overhaul Entire Mac Line With AI-Focused M4 Chips ”. Overhauled line-up! AI-focused chips!重大新闻！

The company, which released its first Macs with M3 chips five months ago, is already nearing production of the next generation — the M4 processor — according to people with knowledge of the matter. The new chip will come in at least three main varieties, and Apple is looking to update every Mac model with it, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the plans haven't been announced.

The new Macs are underway at a critical time. After peaking in 2022, Mac sales fell 27% in the last fiscal year, which ended in September. In the holiday period, revenue from the computer line was flat. Apple attempted to breathe new life into the Mac business with an M3-focused launch event last October, but those chips didn't bring major performance improvements over the M2 from the prior year.

It is true that Mac sales were down considerably last year , but Gurman is painting that as the result of the M3 generation being a meh upgrade compared to M2. But (a) the M3 chips only started shipping in the most recently reported quarter; (b) they're a fine generational upgrade compared to the M2 chips. The real problem is that laptop sales shot up considerably during COVID, with so many people working from home and kids “going to school” via Zoom from home. MacBook sales were pulled forward, so a dip seemed inevitable, no matter how good the M2 and M3 offerings were. And Apple silicon was so good right out of the gate that most people who own M1 Macs — any M1 Macs, including the base MacBook Air and Mac Mini — have little reason to consider upgrading yet.

Apple also is playing catch-up in AI, where it's seen as a laggard to Microsoft Corp., Alphabet Inc.'s Google and other tech peers. The new chips are part of a broader push to weave AI capabilities into all its products.

Back in 2007, Joe Biden dropped a zinger during a presidential primary debate: “Rudy Giuliani, there's only three things he mentions in a sentence: a noun, a verb, and 9/11.” This year, product rumors need only three things: a noun, a verb, and “AI”.

Apple shares climbed 4.3% to $175.04 on Thursday in New York, the biggest single-day gain in 11 months. They had been down 13% this year through Wednesday's close.

Bloomberg gonna Bloomberg .

Apple is aiming to release the updated computers beginning late this year and extending into early next year. There will be new iMacs, a low-end 14-inch MacBook Pro, high-end 14-inch and 16-inch MacBook Pros, and Mac minis — all with M4 chips. But the company's plans could change. An Apple spokesperson declined to comment. [...]

The move will mark a quick refresh schedule for the iMac and MacBook Pro, as both lines were just updated in October. The Mac mini was last upgraded in January 2023.

Apple is then planning to follow up with more M4 Macs throughout 2025. That includes updates to the 13-inch and 15-inch MacBook Air by the spring, the Mac Studio around the middle of the year, and the Mac Pro later in 2025. The MacBook Air received the M3 chip last month, while the Mac Studio and Mac Pro were updated with M2 processors last year.

If all this pans out, it will indeed be news, but the news will be that Apple has successfully gotten the entire Mac hardware lineup onto an annual upgrade cycle. Whereas Gurman is framing the news as a reactionary response by Apple, “overhauling” the hardware lineup very shortly after a supposedly tepid reaction to the M3 generation of Macs that, at this writing, still hasn't completed rolling out.

The M4 chip line includes an entry-level version dubbed Donan, more powerful models named Brava and a top-end processor codenamed Hidra. The company is planning to highlight the AI processing capabilities of the components and how they'll integrate with the next version of macOS, which will be announced in June at Apple's annual developer conference.

I'm sure Apple will have much to say about “AI” at WWDC this June, and that M4-based Macs will execute AI features faster and more efficiently than previous chips, but that's what new chips do for everything . They're faster.

That they will provide Apple with AI-related performance to brag about just means they'll have faster GPUs and bigger Neural Engines, which is exactly how Apple silicon has been evolving year-over-year for 15 years, dating back to the original iPad in 2010 and its A4 SoC . No one is postulating that M4-based Macs will offer AI features that require M4 chips.

The Mac Pro remains the lower-selling model in the company's computer lineup, but it has a vocal fan base. After some customers complained about the specifications of Apple's in-house chips, the company is looking to beef up that machine next year. [...] As part of the upgrades, Apple is considering allowing its highest-end Mac desktops to support as much as a half-terabyte of memory. The current Mac Studio and Mac Pro top out at 192 gigabytes — far less capacity than on Apple's previous Mac Pro, which used an Intel Corp. processor. The earlier machine worked with off-the-shelf memory that could be added later and handle as much as 1.5 terabytes. With Apple's in-house chips, the memory is more deeply integrated into the main processor, making it harder to add more.

Raising the memory ceiling from 192 GB to 512 GB is also news, but surely is the natural progression of the platform, not a response to criticism of the M2 Mac Pro being little more than a Mac Studio with more options for I/O expansion. No one knows better than Apple that the first-generation Apple silicon Mac Pros are a bit of a disappointment. Raising the memory ceiling to 512 GB would be a significant improvement from the M2 Ultra, but would still offer just one-third the RAM ceiling of the 2019 Intel-based Mac Pro.

Anyway, “ the entire Mac product line is set for annual speed-bump Apple silicon updates ” is, as far as I can tell, the actual story. Not “ Mac sales are in the tank and Apple is overhauling the whole product line to change its focus to AI. ”

entry.title: ★ Making a Mountain Out of Molehill-Sized M4 News

entry.summary: To sum up my stance: Tracking is wrong when it's done without consent, and when users have no idea what's being tracked or how it's being used. Tracking is fine when it's done with consent, and users know what's being tracked and how it's being used.
entry.content:
Ian Betteridge , quoting yours truly on non-consensual tracking back in 2020 and then my piece yesterday on the EDPB issuing an opinion against Meta's “Pay or OK” model in the EU:

I wonder what happened to turn John's attitude from “no action Apple can take against the tracking industry is too strong” to defending Facebook's “right” to choose how it invades people's privacy? Or is he suggesting that a private company is entitled to defend people's privacy, but governments are not?

I've seen a bit of pushback along this line recently, more or less asking: How come I was against Meta's tracking but now seem for it? I don't see any contradiction or change in my position though. The only thing I'd change in the 2020 piece Betteridge quotes is this sentence, which Betteridge emphasizes: “No action Apple can take against the tracking industry is too strong.” I should have inserted an adjective before “tracking” — it's non-consensual tracking I object to, especially tracking that's downright surreptitious. Not tracking in and of itself.

That's why I remain a staunch supporter of Apple's App Tracking Transparency, and consider it a success. Apple didn't ban the use of the IDFA for cross-app tracking, and they were correct not to. They simply now require consent. If I had believed that all tracking was ipso facto wrong, I'd have been opposed to ATT on the grounds that it offers the “Allow” choice.

Also from 2020, I quoted Steve Jobs on privacy :

Privacy means people know what they're signing up for, in plain English, and repeatedly.这就是它的意思。 I'm an optimist, I believe people are smart. And some people want to share more data than other people do.问他们。 Ask them every time. Make them tell you to stop asking them if they get tired of your asking them. Let them know precisely what you're going to do with their data.

That's what ATT does. And that's what's Meta's “Pay or OK” model in the EU does. It offers users a clear fair choice: Use Facebook and Instagram free of charge with targeted ads, or pay a reasonable monthly fee for an ad-free experience. No less than Margrethe Vestager herself, back in 2018, was keen on this idea :

My concern is more about whether we get the right choices. I would like to have a Facebook in which I pay a fee each month, but I would have no tracking and advertising and the full benefits of privacy. It is a provoking thought after all the Facebook scandal. This market is not being explored.

Now Meta is “exploring” that market, but the European Commission doesn't like the results, because it turns out that when given the clear choice, the overwhelming majority of EU denizens prefer to use Meta's platforms free-of-charge with targeted ads 。

The best aspects of the EU's digital privacy laws are those that give people the right to know what data is being collected , where it's being stored, who it's being shared with, etc. That's all fantastic. But the worst aspect is the paternalism. The EU is correct to require that users be required to provide consent before being tracked across properties. And Apple is correct for protecting unique device IDFA identifiers behind a mandatory “ Ask App Not to Track / Allow ” consent alert. But Jobs was right too: people are smart, and they can — and should be allowed to — make their own decisions. And many people are more comfortable with sharing data than others. The privacy zealots leading this crusade in the EU do not think people are smart, and do not think they should be trusted to make these decisions for themselves.

I don't like Meta as a company. If a corporation can be smarmy, Meta is that. And they've done a lot of creepy stuff over the years, and for a long while clearly acted as though they were entitled to track whatever they could get away with technically. I suspect they thought that if they asked for consent, or made clear what and how they tracked, that users would revolt. But it turns out billions of people who enjoy Meta's platforms are fine with the deal.

It's obviously the case that for some people, Meta's past transgressions are unforgivable. That's each person's decision to make for themselves. Me, I believe in mercy . Again, I still don't really like the company, by and large. But Threads is pretty good. And sometimes, when I occasionally check in, Instagram can still make me smile. It's very clear what I'm sharing with Meta when I use those apps, and I'm fine with that. If you're not, don't use them. (I've still never created a Facebook blue app account, and still feel like I haven't missed out on a damn thing.)

To sum up my stance: Tracking is wrong when it's done without consent, and when users have no idea what's being tracked or how it's being used. Tracking is fine when it's done with consent, and users know what's being tracked and how it's being used. Privacy doesn't mean never being tracked. It means never being tracked without clear consent. I think Meta is now largely, if not entirely, on the right side of this.

It's paternalistic — infantilizing even — to believe that government bureaucrats should take these decisions out of the hands of EU citizens. Me, I trust people to decide for themselves. The current European Commission regime is clearly of the belief that all tracking is wrong, regardless of consent. That's a radical belief that is not representative of the public. The government's proper role is to ensure people can make an informed choice, and that they have control over their own data. That's what I thought four years ago, and it's what I think now.
